Description: Sherd of Clazomenian black-figure pottery neck-amphora; tongue pattern in black, white and purple on shoulder; two ithyphalic satyrs, with long hair and horses hoofs, pursuing a Maenad; below a row of dots and a frieze of sphinxes to left. Whole, as preserved: Body, A, tongues (dark, white, dark, purple); B, ?: A, satyr grasping the arm of a maenad who looks back (the nose and heel of the maenad preserved); B, satyr chasing two maenads: dividing band of alternate dots: sphinxes (there were originally five): on the dark paint two bands of purple. Purple for hair, ear, white of eye, glans penis of satyrs; stripe above belt of maenad; fillet, stripe on forepart of wing, stripe on each side of junction of tail of sphinxes. Two sphinxes have white whites to their eyes.
Curator's comments: Reconstructed with BM GR 1888,0208.75.c and 1888,0208.111 CVA British Museum 8 Perhaps to A belong the sherds GR 1952.5-5.3 (Pl. 587.5) and Philadelphia E.201.A.1 (body, —: sphinxes), and possibly also E.156.B.2 (body, woman: dividing band of alternate dots: sphinx). Philadelphia E.201.B.2 (neck, A and B, sphinx) might be from the same pot. This amphora has exceptionally a sharp angle at the shoulder (cutting across the tongues): there is another angular shoulder on Philadelphia E. 147.28 (BSA xlvii, 128-B.3a). For the rendering of the further eyebrow and moustache of the satyr of A compare a Fikellura sherd in Samos from the German excavations (K.1027: BSA xxxiv, 19-K.6: head of a satyr, probably contemporary). BMC B.113. F. Dummler, Jdl 1895, 43 fig. 5. BSA xlvii, 128-B.9 (and 9a-b).
Bibliographic references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum (B113)
CVA British Museum 8 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 13, British Museum 8 (Pl. GB 583, 2-4)
Weber 2012 / Untersuchungen zur archaischen griechischen Keramik aus anderen ägyptischen Fundorten (TD 103)
